awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Collaborative Research: Non-Membrane, Low Temperature and Low Emission Water Desalination Using Directional Solvent
awd_abstract_narration:
1510826/1512113
Luo / Shah

Project Overview:

Water scarcity is among the most serious challenges faced by the world today. Desalination has emerged as a potential solution. This collaborative project will examine a novel water desalination technology which does not use membranes.

Current water desalination technologies are either evaporation-based or membrane-based, and they are costly and energy intensive, and also contribute to global-warming CO2 emissions. The proposed research will be driven by the hypothesis that the water solubility in directional solvents can be tuned by varying their molecular structures. Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations will be performed to calculate the phase-equilibria of directional solvents with salt and water as a function of temperature. The knowledge of interactions, obtained from the simulations, between the functional groups and water will form the basis of a correlation between the chemical structure and directionality of water and salt solubilities in the solvent, enabling rational design of high-performance directional solvents. According to the extracted trend, high throughput experimental screening of promising directional solvents will be performed to identify highly efficient directional solvents. Based on the directional solvents, a lab-scale continuous desalination system will be designed and demonstrated.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives in this project were to: (1) design highly efficient directional solvents(DS) for a novel water desalination technology, and (2) based on these solvents, design and demonstrate a continuousdesalination system which is clean, membrane-free and can utilize very low temperature heat sources. The proposed research was driven by the hypothesis that the water solubility in DSs can be tuned by varying their molecular structures. Molecular dynamics simulations were performed to calculate the solvation free energies of DSs with salt and water. The knowledge of interactions, obtained from the simulations, between the functional groups and water will form the basis of a correlation between the chemical structure and directionality of water and salt solubilities in the solvent, enabling rational design of high-performance DSs. A lab-scale continuous desalination system has been designed and demonstrated. 

The proposed work draws from a novel desalination technology known as directional solvent extraction(DSE). This technology relies on a kind of DS with the following properties: the solvent can dissolve water but is insoluble in it; the water solubility increases with temperature; and the solvent does not dissolve salt ions. Using the directional solubilities, fresh water can be extracted from saline sources and released using a DS, with a temperature difference (thermal cycling) being the driving force. The key advantages of this DSE process are: it only requires very low temperature heat sources (as low as 40 oC); the solvent can be recycled so that none of it is consumed; and it avoids the need of membranes which are costly and prone to fouling. The low-temperature feature of DSE enables the utilization of low-temperature thermal energy sources such as solar thermal energy and waste heat which are renewable, cheap and clean.Such a technology has the potential to significantly reduce the costs and reliance on fossil fuels of desalination. The currently used DS, decanoic acid, can recover 0.5% w/w fresh water (fresh water/DS) when operating between 34 oC and 40 oC. The performance of the DSE process, however, can be greatly enhanced with the increase in the DS’ fresh water recovery capacity. The outcome of this research has provided useful guidelines for design DSs, and a continuous desalination system has been developed which is key to its future practical applications. The combination of molecular modelingallowed in-silicoevaluation of the propensity of solvents for water and salt and simultaneously experimental validation of this approach for promising solvents. Further, such an approach has generated fundamental understanding of water interactions in the solvents. The demonstration of the first continuous DSE prototype is achieved and it is a critical step towards the real deployment of this low-cost and sustainable desalination technology.  

Water scarcity is among the most serious challenges faced by the world today. Desalination has emerged as a potential solution. Current water desalination technologies are either evaporation-based or membrane-based, and they are costly and energy intensive, and also contribute to global-warming CO2emissions. Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulation methodologies used in the project has been integrated into the graduate course – Engineering at the Molecular-Level at Notre Dame by PI Luo. The students engaged in this research have benefited from a combined atomistic simulations and experimental approach allowing them to make an intellectual link between the atomistic details of interactions and their manifestation at a systems level. The DSE technology has also been demonstrated to general public through the Energy Week outreach activity. This project also involved three undergraduate students, who have been exposed to an important field related to water and energy.
